Review Surface chemistry of MXene quantum dots: Virus mechanism-inspired mini-lab for catalysis Yuhua Liu Wei Zhang * Weitao Zheng # Key Laboratory of Automobile Materials MOE, and School of Materials Science & Engineering, and Jilin Provincial International Cooperation Key Laboratory of High-Efficiency Clean Energy Materials, and Electron Microscopy Center, and International Center of Future Science, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China Key Laboratory of Automobile Materials MOE and School of Materials Science & Engineering and Jilin Provincial International Cooperation Key Laboratory of High-Efficiency Clean Energy Materials and Electron Microscopy Center and International Center of Future Science Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130012 China Key Laboratory of Automobile Materials MOE, and School of Materials Science & Engineering, and Jilin Provincial International Cooperation Key Laboratory of High-Efficiency Clean Energy Materials, and Electron Microscopy Center, and International Center of Future Science, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China * Corresponding author. Tel/Fax: +86-431-85167218 Tel/Fax: +86-431-85167218 # Corresponding author. Tel/Fax: +86-431-85168246 Tel/Fax: +86-431-85168246 Scientific research is currently more interdisciplinary. Researchers have parsed the surface structure of virus, constructed the interaction model of virus-receptors, offering the clues for studying efficient targeted drugs. Likewise, catalysis is also highly relevant to modern human life. Exploring the surface structure and physicochemical properties of catalysts is of great significance for the design of efficient catalysts. Great progresses have been made for endowing specific physicochemical properties of catalysts through controlling the size of materials and coordination chemistry of active sites, particularly at nanometer scale since Sir John Meurig Thomas and Tao Zhang's early ground-breaking contribution, with casting on a very surface issue. Herein, functional regulation renders the emerging MXene quantum dots (MQDs) excel in contrast to the typical carbon-based quantum dots. In fact, similar to the interaction of virus-receptors model, the surface functional groups decorated MQDs provide a mini-lab to afford a variety of adjustments, involved with the type modification and electronic structure tuning of groups as well as their arrangement, together with the interaction between the groups and active materials/support, ultimately for packaging or designing high-activity catalysts. Graphical Abstract XXX Keywords Surface chemistry Functional group Structure characterization MXene Quantum dot 1 Introduction In top-down styles, single site heterogeneous catalyst (SSHC) initiated by Sir John Meurig Thomas affords to modify the structure of active site centers, where each single sites meet the same energy (the interaction of active site-reactant), leading to a high catalytic selectivity [1]. In 2011, the emergence of single atoms (SAs) broke out this idealization, and the exploration of interaction between SAs and coordinatively unsaturated support becomes one of the central issues [2]. As the smallest functional materials, SAs can achieve chemical catalysis and physical manipulation, uncovering a newly-discovered fertile area [3–5]. This is perfect feedback to Richard Feynman's saying (Nobel Laureate, 1965) “There is Plenty of Room at the Bottom” in 1959, revealing the possibility to manipulate and control of matter at the nanoscale [6]. Such breakthrough inheriting regulation of the coordination environment and electronic structure of active sites in SSHC. Obviously, engineering the active sites offers unlimited possibility for guiding the design of catalysts towards expected properties. For the catalytic activity, however, the fully exposed Pd metal clusters are superior to Pd SAs, representing atomic dispersion shall not always beneficial to a catalytic reaction [7]. Invertedly for the extremely smaller (top-down), a slight bottom-up of extending to dual-atoms, tri-atoms, and even clusters [8,9], as well as constructing the exposed planes toward the desired activities enables shaping and maximizing the reactivity and atom utilization. Demonstrably, these pioneering views showed that controlling the size of materials, and the charge structure of active sites have profound impact on their catalytic activity. It is worth mentioning that the reduction of size increases the contact areas of catalyst with reaction environment, inducing a high surface reactivity per unit mass [10,11]. Thus, the surface chemistry of catalyst affects the adsorption and desorption of reactants, intermediates and products. Such relationship of surface − reaction activity is traced back to explore the reaction mechanism of ammonia synthesis (invented by Fritz Haber, Nobel Laureate 1918) [12], that is, the decisive step lies in the interaction of N2 with the catalyst surface to promote N≡N cleavage (improved by Carl Bosch, Nobel Laureate 1931) [13–16]. This is consistent with “the theory of surface adsorption chemical bond” in heterogeneous catalysis proposed by Dayu Zhang in 1960 [17], with which the adsorption heat and number of active centers determine the activity of catalyst. Reducing the size of bulk materials to the nanoscale of 2–10 nm, the fundamental changes occur for the physicochemical properties, e.g., quantum confinement effects and small size effect [18–20], thereby affecting the catalytic activity. The development of semiconductor quantum dots has witnessed from carbon materials to MXene, including carbon nanodots (CNDs), carbon quantum dots (CQDs), graphene quantum dots (GQDs), carbonized polymer dots (CPDs), and MXene quantum dots (MQDs). In MQDs, MXene with long-range ordered MX atom arrangement obtained by selectively etching “A” atom layers from the MAX (M: transition metal, X: carbides, nitrides or carbonitrides, A: IIIA metal). In addition, the surface functional groups of QDs play a decisive role in catalytic reactions. Nevertheless, the construction of crystal lattice far exceeds the simplicity of carbon, bring more expected tremendous performance change as translational-symmetry interior and termination (Figs. 1(a) and (b) ) [21]. Currently, more efforts are made to explore the surface chemistry of 2D MXene for improving their catalytic activity. Controlling the type, contents of functional groups favor for selecting favorable catalytic sites; also constructing 2D MXene-based heterostructure enables maximizing the number of active sites, where the negative groups play an important role in hierarchical structure [23–26]. Moreover, as density functional theory (DFT) also shows, as the surface groups sites of 2D MXene can be decorated by heteroatoms, it can tune effectively the interaction between reactants and active site [27–29]. As such surface chemistry provides the opportunities to tailor the interaction of surface-environment, it is particularly important for the MQDs with high surface energy. However, there are seldom reports concerning with such engineering strategy in MQDs (Fig. 1(c)). Such nanotechnology is similar to study the interaction between the raised coronal spike glycoprotein at coronavirus outer layer (Fig. 1(d)) and surface receptor of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), for further developing the delicate drugs and therapy antibody that inhibits their contact, which is an exciting progress [22]. Herein, as single site chemical species of MQDs, surface functional groups can serve as a mini-lab, providing plenty of room to design MQDs-based catalysts (Fig. 2 ). 2 Mechanism of catalysis 2.1 Electrocatalysis Currently, MXene has been widely used in electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [24,30,31]. The surface functional sites of MXene as adsorption and desorption location of reactants and products, plays an important role in catalytic reaction. However, compared to 2D MXene nanosheets and 1D nanowires, 0D MQDs possess unique surface effect, size effect and edge effect, endowing excellent catalytic activity (Fig. 3(a) ). Most research shows that 0D MQDs provide abundant edge active sites, affording the properties superior to 2D counterparts (Fig. 3(b)) [32–44]. In different electrocatalytic reactions, it depends on the binding energy required for the thermodynamic rate-determining step in order to identify the real active sites in functional groups. Usually, the surface of MXene will be covered by preparation–derived electronegative groups, such as −F, −OH, −Cl, etc. [45,46]. Jin et al. [47] calculated the free energy of Ti-edge, Ti atoms in perfect plane, −OH and −F (Fig. 4(a) ). It shows that higher active Ti-edge sites and −OH groups are favorable for NRR; the bare Ti-edge and −F groups provide good HER activity. Thus, the DFT results guide for the synthesis of Ti3C2OH MQDs with abundant Ti-edge sites, which, together with −OH, promote the adsorption and activation of N2 molecules. As a result, it contributes to excellent NRR performance, and the yield of NH3 is far higher than 2D Ti3C2T x MXene and Ti3C2F2 (Fig. 4(b)). Furthermore, 2D Ti2C MXene with abundant −F terminal has shown higher HER activity, which is consistent with the DFT result [43]. Except for the surface functional group as active sites, constructing surface defects in MQDs can also promote the electrocatalytic reaction. The defect sites with high activation energy are beneficial to adjust the adsorption of reactant. It is noticed that Ti-edges are almost inert during electrocatalytic HER [48–50]. However, compared to 2D MXene nanosheet, the introduction of defects (grain boundary, edge defects) in MQDs contributes to optimize local unsaturated coordination state of active sites and low coordinated Ti/C atoms. As a result, the variation of electronic structure of catalysts is induced, leading to a favorable rearrangement of electrons (Figs. 4(c), (d), and (g)). Thus, the adsorption energy of O2 and LiO2, and overall electrocatalytic reaction kinetics were enhanced tremendously for Li-O2 batteries (Figs. 4(e), (f), (h), and (i)) [51]. Moreover, designing MQDs-based heterostructure catalyst helps to integrate the advantages of different components, and the interface interaction between phases can facilitate high-effective electrons transfer for the promising stability of catalytic reaction. For example, Liu et al. [52] synthesized Ti2CT x MQDs/Cu2O/Cu foam heterostructure by self-assemble method. The presence of Cu2O not only promotes the distribution of MQDs, but also the excellent interface charge transfer enhances charge transfer efficiency (Fig. 4(j)). Finally, the abundant oxygen functional groups were produced via spontaneous substitution in MQDs as catalytic active sites, and thereof outstanding HER performance and stability is achieved (Fig. 4(k)). The activity of MQDs is superior to 2D Ti2CT x MXene nanosheet, ascribed to the abundant edge effect and heterogeneous interface of 0D MQDs. In summary, the electrocatalytic mechanism of MQDs is mainly correlated to the adsorption and desorption of reactants (H2O, H3O+, N2, O2, CH4), products (H2, H2O2, NH3), occurring at the active sites of MQDs. Parsing the interaction between active sites and reactants/products is similar to the study of receptor binding domain of the new coronavirus S protein, protecting the interaction of new coronavirus from infecting human cells (e.g., coronavirus-ACE2) [53], identifying the structure of active sites for an optimal design. Some strategies such as controlling the types of surface functional groups, constructing MQDs-based heterostructure, introducing surface defects, etc. have been used to improved electrode reaction process. Currently, it is the fertile land for the electrocatalytic application of MQDs, more mechanism remains to be explored. 2.2 Photocatalysis Compared to 2D MXene nanosheet, the energy level splitting of 0D MQDs near the Femi level is due to quantum confinement effect, leading to the controllable bandgap (Fig. 5(a) ). Thus, it improves the utilization of visible light, enabling that the photocatalytic activity can be effectively regulated [54,55]. To improve poor activity of semiconductors photocatalyst, the introduction of MQDs as co-catalyst is an effective strategy. Moreover, as an excellent photocatalyst, there are some factors needs to be considered [56]: (1) Broad spectral response range for producing more photogenerated electrons. (2) Suitable energy band position for avoiding recombination of photogenerated carriers. (3) Long-term stability. (4) Strong redox ability. Therefore, on the one hand, the photoluminescence behavior of MQDs helps to enhance light adsorption range, on the other hand, construct heterogeneous junction based on the energy level position of MQDs and catalyst, as it can effectively increase the extraction of photogenerated electrons, contributing to fast surface redox reactions (Fig. 5(b)). Currently, a variety of possible mechanisms have been proposed for construction of MQDs-based heterojunction catalysts. When the photocatalyst is irradiated by simulated solar light, the photocatalyst absorbs photons, and then electrons are excited from valence band (VB) of the catalyst to the conduction band (CB), while leaving holes in the VB. Also, the unstable photons are prone to easily spontaneous transit back to the VB, and recombine with holes, thereby reducing the lifetime of photogenerated carriers. Ascribed to the abundant surface functional groups of MQDs, it is easily offered to combine with other semiconductor photocatalysts. Thus, it is important for optimizing interfacial charge transfer between the heterojunctions to promote photocatalytic activity. Moreover, the position of CB and VB can be calculated on the basis on the spectral data of different materials, which contributes to simulate the migration path of electron-hole pairs, and understand the reaction mechanism. For example, Fig. 6(a) show the energy band structure of Ti3C2 MQDs and Ni-MOF [57]. The internal electric field (IEF) is generated at the interface, which promotes the transfer of electrons and holes. Also, MQDs not only act as electron donors for Ni-MOF, avoiding the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs in MQDs, enhancing the NRR, but also promoting the process of oxidation reaction from SO3 2– to SO4 2–. Conversely, the MQDs as electrons acceptors, constructing Schottky junction barrier is another effectively strategy for enhancing extraction of photogenerated electron (Fig. 6(b)) [58]. In addition, the Z-Scheme (Fig. 6(c)) and S-Scheme (Figs. 6(d)–(f)) heterojunction photocatalysts are also designed for improving the separation of electron-hole pairs [59,60]. For either two phase or three-phase interfaces, the charge redistribution induced bending of the band edge and formatting an IEF at the interfaces, until their Fermi levels reached the equilibrium. However, most research concentrates on the design of energy band structure in MQDs-based co-catalysts, whereas the impact of surface chemistry is neglected on the light response and redox activity. Therefore, it is necessary to explore more surface modification strategy of MQDs in photocatalytic reaction. 2.3 Photoelectrocatalysis Compared to the electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, the photoelectrocatalysis integrates the advantages of light drive and electric drive. The catalytic reaction is conducted in the simple photoelectrochemical devices. However, their mechanisms are similar. It is need to strictly control light adsorption ability, photogenerated carriers’ separation and surface redox sites. Different from the construction of heterostructure photocatalysis, the introduction of metal cobalt-nanoparticle leads to formation of Co-Ti3C2 MQD Janus-structured, and thereof induces the electron transfer from Co to MQDs (Fig. 6(g)). It not only contributes to promote the broad optical response range and strong light harvesting efficiency of MQD, but also forms Schottky junction that can effectively avoid the photogenerated electron–hole pairs recombination, thereby leading to fast water oxidation dynamics [61]. Furthermore, the MQDs can also couple with photoanode of hole transfer layer (HTL), serve as the reservoirs of photogenerated charges, improving the photogenerated carriers’ separation (Fig. 6(h)) [62]. However, there are seldom research on photoelectrocatalysis of MQDs, and more reaction mechanism remains to be explored. 3 Controllable synthesis of functional groups in MQDs The researchers analyzed the interaction domains between viruses and human proteins for tailoring targeted drugs and disrupt the interaction. Inspired by such scenario, the surface groups of MQDs were customized to synthesize efficient catalytic active sites for chemical reactions. The surface functional groups of MQDs (e.g., −O, −OH, −Cl, −Br, −F, −NH2) plays an important role in different catalytic reaction, including the adsorption of reactants, and control the interaction of heterogeneous interface. Therefore, its controllable synthesis is required. At present, there are some articles addressing the synthesis of MQDs with specific functional groups (Table 1 ). The type of functional groups relates to the choice of etchant, added inorganic ions, and subsequent processing during the preparation of 2D MXene. Currently, the precursor material of MQDs is usually 2D MXene, thus the functional groups of MQDs depend on the 2D counterpart. The preparation of 2D MXene is mainly divided into fluorine-containing and fluorine-free routes, leading to the −F groups on surface of MQDs. The fluorine-containing etchants includes HF acid and NH4F2, while the HCl + LiF etchant can introduce two groups of −F and −Cl [63]. Furthermore, the etch routes of water–contains will introduce abundant oxygen groups (–O, −OH), with the contents of −O higher than −OH. Currently, the presence of −F is beneficial to promote the proton adsorption kinetics, and induced excellent HER performance [43]. Therefore, the MQDs with the mixed of −F, −O and −OH groups can be prepared via hydrothermal, solvothermal, mechanical ultrasound, and microwave irradiation methods (Figs. 7(a) and (b) ). The Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) confirms the formation of functional groups (Figs. 7(c) and (d)) [58,64]. However, considering the characteristics of safe and environmentally friendly, F-free routes such as Lewis acidic etching (e.g., ZnCl2, CuCl2) [65,66], alkaline etching (e.g., NaOH, TMAOH) [67–69], enable obtaining the MXene completely covered by −Cl or −OH groups. Moreover, the electrochemical etching is also another strategy, and the groups relate to the electrolyte [37]. In addition, for determining the role of single group in catalysis, the alkalinization and annealing is applied to obtain −OH and −O groups, respectively [40,43,70,71]. For example, the Ti3C2Cl2 MXene was prepared by Lewis acidic etching (CdCl2), and then the QDs-Ti3C2Cl2 was synthesized via hydrothermal routes (Figs. 7(e) and (f)) [72]. Such single groups contribute to explore the real catalytic active sites. Therefore, controlling the surface groups of MQDs by adjusting the surface functional groups of 2D MXene requires complex steps, and there are many factors to be controlled, which is not conducive to obtaining high-quality MQDs (purity, crystallinity, atomic arrangement, and defects). In contrast, the single functional groups obtained during the preparation of quantum dots have been reported. Simultaneously, the substitution reaction of functional groups also occurs. For instance, the −OH groups terminated Ti3C2 MQDs can be synthesized via alkalization of NaOH and mechanical shearing. The −F groups of MXene via HF etching were substituted by −OH in this process [47]. Similarly, the −Cl groups can also be substituted by −O groups during electrochemical reaction process, which relate to the electronegativity of groups [52]. Moreover, for avoiding the F-containing etching, Xu et al. [73] prepared Ti3C2 MQDs with −O and −OH by sonication route. The interaction of tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) and Al atomic layer induced the successful exfoliation of MXene, and further bath sonication promotes the formation of MQDs (Fig. 7(g)), and the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) shows the presence of O-containing groups (Fig. 7(h)). The catalytic activity of O-containing groups can be clearly researched due to no other effects of functional groups. Therefore, the surface functional groups can be effectively controlled by muti-steps or simple routes, which contribute to the detailed research for different catalytic reaction. 4 Design principles of Single site chemistry in MQDs Since 2017, it has witnessed the soaring development of 2D MXene derived MQDs, however, remains to be exploratory stage in their synthesis and application. Different from the formation of surface functional groups at carbon quantum dots, the groups of MQDs are originated from the electronegative groups (–F, −Cl, −O, and −OH) adsorbed on the highly active M–terminals during the etching of the “A” layers of MAX phase [82]. Thus, the catalytic performance of MQDs is inseparable from their parent MXenes. Furthermore, various types of functional groups are not conducive to figure out the real catalytic active sites. Understanding the role of specific groups is of great significance for identifying real catalytic active sites, illustrating the reaction mechanism, and revealing the real catalytic process. Currently, identifying the role of CDs, and designing of active sites of CDs-based catalysts has been gradually mature. However, MQDs as an emerging nanomaterial, there is seldom report on the single site modification methods in catalytic field. As a result, we discuss the design principle of MQDs learned from CD-based catalyst. 4.1 Importance of functional groups Researchers have identified many randomly arranged spike proteins on the surface of each new coronavirus particle (virion), meaning they are the key to the fusion of the virus and human cells. In parallel to such importance, surface functional groups may offer their practical application as an important component of MQDs. In the functional CQDs, GQDs and CPDs, benefited from surface defects (functional groups) and abundant edge sites, many works have demonstrated that the surface groups of CDs play important roles in electrocatalysis [83–85]. However, as the advantage of functional groups lies at not just a matter of size, it affords more unique properties from the chemistry to nanoscience. For example, the free-standing silicon nanoparticles with chiral achieved by the synergy effects between the surface functional groups of tryptophan and Si [86], highlighting the importance of ligand chemistry. Furthermore, at the nanoscale, the GQDs with −NH2 functional groups has the nontoxic and environmentally friendly merits, acting as the carbon support to anchor single atoms [87]. The strong chelation effect between the metal cations and −NH2 avoid the aggregation of metal atoms, and limit the growth and size of single atoms by spatial confinement [88]. Reunion of noble metal Ru is the main reason for the decline of electrocatalytic activity. Li et al. [89] reported three support of Ru nanoparticles. Benefiting from the strong interaction between functional groups of CDs and d orbitals of Ru, the aggregation of Ru is limited, leading to high crystallinity of Ru@CDs (Fig. 8(a) ). On the contrary, the Ru@Porphyra (PC) and Ru@activated carbon (AC) shows obvious aggregation (Figs. 8(b) and (c)), contributing to the poor catalytic activity (Fig. 8(d)). Meanwhile, the surface groups further promote the inter-connection of QDs, or splicing/self-cross-linking into a layered conductive network, offering abundant edges and terminations, maximizing the interaction between electrolytes, reactants and electrons [90–92]. Furthermore, the presence of small size QDs can limit the morphology by the interaction of QDs-metal, leading to optimized interfaces. For example, the Co nanoparticles are encapsulated by N-CD, enable the controlled growth of uniform Co morphology and avoid the oxidation of Co2+ [93]. The TEM image clearly shows the existence of the carbon shell (Fig. 8(e)). Such confinement effect makes the cobalt catalysis the maximized activity (Fig. 8(f)). Simultaneously, the small size of QDs is factually a pool of more anchored sites to increase the loadings of single atoms. Under the same interaction, the QDs with O-containing functional groups as the tethered sites to anchor transition metal single atoms, achieving high catalytic selectivity and activity [94]. It is worth mentioning that when QDs are used as a functional carrier, the electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) promotes electrons redistribution at interface, accelerating the reaction process, which is similar to the well-known strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [95]. In contrast, the surface functional groups of MQDs provides favorable catalytic activity. Thus, it is needed to consider controlling both the types of surface functional group and the degree of oxidation of surface oxygen functional groups of MQDs, and further modifying the functional groups to reduce the catalytic reaction energy barrier [96,97]. Additionally, as MQDs as the emerging disciplines of nanomaterials, the unique surface advantage provides more possibility and promises for designing high-performance catalyst. 4.2 Importance of surface defects For electrocatalysis, surface defects can improve local unsaturated coordination state of active sites. Thus, it helps to control electronic structure, reduce the binding energy between catalyst surface and reactants, thereby enhancing the oxide reaction kineties. For example, Wang et al. [51] synthesizes Ti3C2 MQDs clusters offered with rich crystal defects. Compared to layered MXene, 0D MQDs shows abundant edge defects and grain boundary (Figs. 9(a) and (b) ). Such defects can be confirmed by electron paramagnetic resonance spectra (EPR) (Fig. 9(c)). Experiments combined with DFT calculations indicate that this crystal defect-controlled catalytic center provides a fundamental role in inducing charge density delocalization, regulating Li x O y intermediate adsorption, and reducing redox energy barriers. In another example, the H2O2 oxidation promote the production of Ti n O2n−1 quantum dots abundant with oxygen vacancies (Figs. 9(d) and (e)) [98]. It regulates the adsorption and conversion of Li2S4 (Fig. 9(f)), and thus improving the stability and long-Life of Li-S batteries. However, the application of surface defects of MQDs in other electrocatalytic reaction (e.g., HER, OER, ORR) remains to be achieved. For photocatalysis, the light response range and photogenerated electrons-hole pairs separation ability determines reaction rate. Research shows that the functional modification can induce fluorescence quenching by the interaction between groups (e.g., metal ions), thereof avoiding the carrier's recombination [99,100]. Moreover, the effect of surface defects in MQDs on the photoluminescence properties is mainly attributed to the recombination pathway variation of excitons (Fig. 9(g)), and it is beneficial to the overall photocatalytic reaction. Such mechanism can explain that photo-excited electrons may first relax to the defect energy level, leading to a change in the dynamic direction of the excitons, and thereof resulting in non-radiative transitions. As a result, the luminescent capability of quantum dots will be weakened. Ai et al. [101] studied amino-functionalized Ti3C2 MQDs, and the interaction between −NH2 and oxygen-containing groups induced bright blue fluorescence (FL). The FL mechanism is found to be attributed to surface defects and size effects. And then, the introduction of Ni2+ contributed to the FL quenching (Fig. 9(h)). It provides an idea that help to design excellent photocatalysts with high extraction rate of photogenerated electrons. In the wet chemical etching process of MXene, the research has shown that MXenes enable producing different types of surface defects (metal vacancies, or C/N vacancies), which due to the differences of chemical environment (pH, type of functional group, applied voltage) [102]. However, there are seldom reports on the application of surface defects of MQDs in photocatalysis, and the formation mechanism of surface defect remains to be further identified. 4.3 Importance of support The metal-free carbon is not an ideal choice of catalyst, but their excellent conductivity is the first choice for preparing composites. In contrast, CQDs with amounts of edge sites can act as the active sites to promote the adsorption and desorption of reactants and productions. Similar to carbon-based QDs, MQDs can also serve as ideal support due to abundant surface functional groups. However, the difference lies in the functional groups of MQDs such as −O, −OH possess favorable catalytic activity for NRR and HER. However, the high surface energy of quantum dots is prone to induce several aggregations. The strong interface coupling between QDs and support (e.g., graphene, nanosheets, MOF, nanowires) can enhance the electron transfer, toward achieving highly catalytic performance [90,103]. Moreover, designing the heterostructure of MQD-support requires to consider the interaction mechanism, including electron transfer path, interface reaction kinetics and the coordination state of groups and the surface of support. 5 Modification strategy of unit point chemistry in MQDs Controlling the electronic structure and physiochemistry properties of MQDs contributes to improve catalytic activity. Research on MQDs in catalysis remains in a booming stage. Therefore, there are seldom reports on design methods of MQDs-based catalyst. Herein, we summarize the present five design strategies, which reveals underlying mechanisms for improving activity depending on both experiments and theory, which can be divided into heteroatomic doping, coordination effect, crosslinked carrier, functional groups substitution and constructing heterojunction. 5.1 Heteroatomic doping Some non-metal atoms (e.g., N, S, Cl and P) has been regarded as ideal dopants for adjusting photoluminescence behavior of MQDs, thereby improving spectral response range and light stability [104–107], which is beneficial to achieve good photocatalytic performance. However, the application of such unique optical properties in the field of photocatalysis remains to be further verified. Moreover, DFT calculation shows that non-metallic P atoms doping helps to narrow the band gap of 2D MXene, thereby improving conductivity (Figs. 10(a)–(d) ). And, the introduction of P atoms also affects the overlap of O 2px orbital and H-1s orbital, facilitating the interaction of O–H (Fig. 10(e)), and accelerating the dissociation processes of H2O molecule and the release of H atoms (Figs. 10(f), (g)). Thus, compared to 2D MXene, 0D MQDs possess broader bandgap due to quantum confinement effect, and such optimization of electronic structure can be applied to electrocatalysis. Furthermore, DFT and experiment shows that the oxygen groups of MXene as real catalytic active sites provide excellent HER performance [40,108]. Also, metal atoms (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni and Mn) can act as dopants to further improve HER activity by controlling the single sites (functional group) activity. The interaction between H and O atoms will be weaken via the electrons transfer of metal-O (Figs. 10(h), (i)). Furthermore, the electronic density near the active sites is related to the electronegative of metal. For example, Ni (1.92) > Co (1.88) > Fe (1.83), the difference charge density (Figs. 10(j)–(m)) shows that the number of electrons transported is different from metal to oxygen, thereby affecting the Gibbs free energy of H atoms. Also, the adsorption position of reactants, and the coverage rate of H atoms can also be considered (Fig. 10(n)). In summary, since there are no reports concerning the effect of heteroatomic doping on catalysis performance in MQDs, we summarize the typical theoretical aspects, contributing to guide the design of MQDs-based catalysts. 5.2 Coordination effect MQDs possess high surface energy due to size effect. Thus, in order to efficiently stabilize quantum dots, and avoid self-aggregation during synthesis and catalysis, the selection of supports is crucial. Currently, different dimensional nanomaterials are frequently selected as support, such as 3D porous metal foam, 2D nanosheets, 1D nanowires. Usually, the selectivity of support needs to meet high conductivity, acid or alkaline solution resistant, and provide excellent interfacial contact with MQDs for promoting efficient interfacial charge transfer capability. For example, the prepared Ti3C2 MQDs by Han et al. [78] are dispersed 2D NiFe layered double hydroxide nanosheet (Figs. 11(a), (c) ), benefited from the electronically coupled of Ni, Fe ions and oxygen functional groups on the surface of MQDs (Fig. 11(b)). The interface charge transfer induced the valence state change, thereby enhancing the electronic conductivity of NiFe LDH. Compared to 0D MQDs, NiFe LDH/MQDs shows excellent OER and ORR performance (Fig. 11(d)). Meanwhile, the presence of 3D porous nitrogen-doped graphene further facilitates mass/ion transport, and exposes more active sites. Moreover, 1D nanowires provides short ions/electrons transmission distance. The Ti3C2 MQDs and MoS2 MQDs were dispersed in the multiwall carbon nanotubes (Fig. 11(e)), and the introduction of QDs induced well-defined interface, thereby promoting the fast charge and ion transfer during ORR and methanol oxidation reaction (Figs. 11(f), (g)) [80]. Different from 2D and 1D nanomaterials, 3D porous structure metal foam not only meets the aforementioned advantages, but also conducive to fully wetting the electrolyte, and releasing the gas-phase products timely, thus promoting highly-efficient HER activity (Figs. 11(h) and (i)) [52]. Therefore, when designing MQDs-based catalyst, it is necessary to consider the coordination effect of MQDs, which has great promotion effect on final performance. 5.3 Crosslinked carrier MXene has been regarded as an ideal carrier due to their tunable band gap, high specific surface area, excellent electronic conductivity and carrier mobility, and high mechanical stability [49,109–111]. Compared to 2D MXene, the unique advantages of MQDs as carrier are that the size of MQDs can be applied to limit the growth of single atoms, nanoparticles, leading to the excellent dispersion. However, such strategy has not been reported so far. In contrast, the carbon-based QDs has been widely studied. In CDs-based catalysts, the self-crosslinked carbon network can be formed via surface functional groups interaction (e.g., −COOH, =O, −NH2), for anchoring single atoms, nanoparticles (Figs. 12(a) and (b) ) [87]. The interaction between functional groups and metal nanoparticles can also limit the aggregation and growth of particles, promising the stability of the reaction process (Figs. 12(c)–(e)) [112]. Such strategy has been wildly popularized. However, there is almost no activity for the CDs with different surface functional groups, which is a flexible support. In contrast, the internal structure of MQDs is complicate. Compositional diversity determines the different structures, resulting in different physicochemical properties. Also, many articles shows that MQDs with different groups terminal provide outstanding electrocatalytic activity [47,52]. In addition, when reducing the size of MXene, the exposed crystal planes may vary, thereof inducing the different catalytic performance of MQDs. For example, DFT calculation shows that the binding energy of Pt-OHad in the surface of Pt nanoparticles will change with size, contributing to the variation of intrinsic activity in different sites (edge, step, terrace) (Fig. 12(f)). And, the activity of Pt (111) and Pt (100) in the real catalytic active sites (terrace sites) are also different (Fig. 12(g)) [113]. Therefore, the functional groups of MQDs can exist in different positions, also leading to the activity difference. For instance, DFT calculation shows that the oxygen can adsorb on the four possible positions (top, fcc, hcp, and bridge) (Fig. 12(h)) [29], and the preferential adsorption sites of oxygen functional groups depend on the detailed MXene compositions. For instance, the O atoms prefer to adsorb on the fcc sites on both sides for Ti2CO2. Whereas for Mo2CO2, the most stable sites are hcp sites, which induced the difference of binding energy between H and O (Figs. 12(i) and (j)). As a result, MQDs-based nanocomposites will exhibit different catalytic performance after self-crosslinking carriers. Currently, such design strategy remains to be achieved. 5.4 Functional groups substitution As well-known, fluorine groups are not conductive to the electrochemical storage process [69,114,115]. However, −F groups are beneficial to catalytic reaction. Li et al. [43] showed that the rich fluorine groups benefit to promote the proton adsorption kinetics and reduce the charge transfer resistance in acid condition, compared to the alkalized MXene during catalytic reaction, the −OH groups show the poor activity (Fig. 13(a) ), DFT calculation indicates that the presence of −F groups can lower Gibbs free energy of H, and the −O and −OH groups also affect the activity of Ti2CF2 (Figs. 13(b) and (c)). Furthermore, the preparation of F-free MXenes is safe and environmentally friendly, but unlocking the catalytic activity of oxygen-containing groups is a key issue. A post-processing such as alkalizing and annealing treatment can obtain −OH terminated and −O terminated MXenes, respectively. It was experimentally found that −O groups have better electrochemical reaction compared with −OH, due to the O sites of basal plane beneficial to immediate adsorption and desorption based on the DFT calculation [40,116]. The above conclusion can be supported by DFT, and Ti2CO2 possess the optimal electrocatalytic hydrogen production in many MXene materials (Fig. 13(d)) [108]. Additionally, the −OH and −O groups are mixed in practical cases. The charge distribution near the O active site effects on the catalytic activity, and the Bader charge and Gibbs free energy calculation reveals the moderate coverage of −OH helps weakening the oxidation of −O groups by controlling the amount of charge near O sites (Figs. 13(e) and (f)), thereby reducing the interaction between the O sites and H atoms, regulating towards the excellent HER performance [117,118]. More importantly, the excellent conductivity of catalyst is a necessity but not sufficient condition for high catalytic activity. The DFT calculation revealed the existence of functional groups not only have effects on the magnetic properties, but also the conductivity of MXenes, proved by the orbital hybridization near the Fermi level. For example, Ti2CO2 possess strong hybridization of Ti 3d-C 2p and Ti 3d-O 2p, leading to a semiconducting property, and all other functional MXene showed a metallic behavior due to the strong orbital hybridization of Ti 3d and O 2p near the Fermi level (Fig. 13(g)). Thus, it is important for calculating of Fermi level [N(EF)] to pinpoint the surface chemistry of layered materials [119]. Moreover, the functional catalysts can be tailored on the basis of the surface functional groups. The above research demonstrates that functional MXene possess excellent catalytic activity. Combined with the development of carbon materials quantum dots in the field of catalysis, the MQDs with different surface functional groups are expected to find better performance. Nevertheless, few studies have concentrated on the competitive advantages of surface functional groups of MQDs in photocatalytic and electrocatalytic reactions. Given that the key role of functional groups on the surface of MXene, and the unique physiochemical properties of MQDs, the functional groups are expected to achieve a maximize utilization. Such advantage has been demonstrated in the MQDs. Jin et al. [47] calculated the activate ability of bare Ti-edge, −F groups, −OH groups for N2 molecules, showing that the abundant −OH groups provide adequate electrons to active N≡N. N2 reduction reaction (NRR) and HER is a pair of competitive reactions, where the −O and −F groups are favorable HER sites (Fig. 13(h)). Thus, it gives theoretical guiding for designing high-performance MQDs-based catalysts for NRR and HER. Also, to maximize the utilization of favorable oxygen-containing groups for HER, the spontaneous functional group evolution is expected from −Cl to −O group in the alkalization condition, toward unlocking excellent HER kinetic process (Fig. 4(k)) [52]. Therefore, compared to carbon materials quantum dots, MQDs provides better intrinsic catalytic performance. 5.5 Constructing heterojunction Constructing heterojunction structure is an effective strategy to improve catalyst activity via integrating different components. Also, the surface reconstruction will generate new crystalline phases, thereby forming new heterojunction. They can induce the electrons redistribution at interface, achieving synergy effects in electrocatalysis. And, the negatively charged surface functional groups plays an important role in nanocomposites. For example, Cheng et al. [120] prepared Ti3C2T x MQDs/Cu heterostructure by electrostatic adsorption (groups and Cu2+) and chemical reduction method for NRR. TEM image indicates that MQDs are uniformly distributed on the surface of Cu nanosheets (Fig. 14(a) ). Compared to the DOS of pure MQDs and Cu side, the higher occupied states of two-phase interface near the Femi level contributes to promote adsorption and activation of N2 molecules (Fig. 14(b)). Moreover, charge difference density can also confirm the abundant electrons accumulated on the interface (Fig. 14(c)). Finally, the synergy effects of MQDs and Cu provides excellent electrocatalytic activity (Fig. 14(d)). Such enhanced strategy can be extended to other electrocatalytic applications. In addition, in photocatalytic reaction, the position of VB and CB (bandgap value) affects the absorption capacity from the ultraviolet to visible region, and the capacity of photogenerated carrier separation. And, the photogenerated carriers’ recombination is a main reason that reduces photocatalytic efficiency, while constructing heterogeneous interface can help to reverse the recombination via inhibiting photogenerated electron backflow. Currently, such reports focus most on the MQDs as co-catalysts to modulate the band structure by forming Schottky junction, S-Scheme and Z-Scheme photocatalysts, leading to broad the spectral response range of the catalysts. Also, as of reducing the recombination of photogenerated carriers, it helps to enhance the redox reactions on the surface of the co-catalysts. The surface of MQDs possess plentiful active functional groups. Thus, as co-catalyst, it not only improves the carrier's recombination behavior, but also enhances surface redox reaction. Yuan et al. [75] synthesized WO3/TQDs/In2S3 Z-scheme heterojunctions composite (Figs. 14(e)–(h)). The Ti3C2T x MQDs as co-catalyst helps to enhance light-trapping ability for producing more photogenerated carriers (Fig. 14(i)), and provides the photocatalytic activity of 3–4 times higher than WO3/In2S3 heterojunctions (Fig. 14(j)). As a result, the schematic diagram of the mechanism shows that the energy level matching between MQDs and photocatalyst is important for effectively avoid photogenerated carriers’ recombination (Fig. 14(k)). Except for synergy effects, the interface-induced stress-strain effect on catalytic activity also needs to be studied. As an emerging semiconductor nanomaterial with unique physicochemical properties, the forming mechanism and evolution process of MQDs-based heterogeneous interface remains to be explored by means of in-situ characterization techniques. 6 Deeply understanding the catalytic mechanism of MQDs 6.1 Ex-situ characterization of MQDs Exploring the limitations of characterization techniques is crucial for deeply understanding the catalytic mechanism of MQDs, e.g., structural and morphology characterizations. Identifying the structure of surface functional groups (active sites) in MQDs contributes to explore catalytic reaction kinetics step and mechanism. Currently, the structural characterization of MQDs consists mainly of Raman spectra, FTIR, UV spectra, XPS and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), utilized to detect the detailed chemistry issues (Fig. 15 ). While the advanced structure characterization technique such as X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) should be considered to study the changes of electronic structure and bonding configuration of surface functional groups at the adsorbed layer, helping to explore the reaction mechanism of heterogeneous catalysis [121–123]. Moreover, the surface chemistry of atomic resolution needs to be achieved by means of modern TEM/scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), especially in Aberration-correction TEM (AC-TEM). In the 2D MXene, the surface metal atoms, −Cl and −Br functional groups can be characterized by atomically resolved HAADF-STEM, combined with the lattice resolved EDS to identifying local structure and compositions (Figs. 16(a)–(c) ) [125,126]. While the surface oxygen atoms, C toms are difficult to be detected due to lower atomic number. Furthermore, the small-size and luminescent MQDs, or some MQDs-based heterostructure catalysts are sensitive to electron beam, contributes to inability to observe the surface configuration and morphology at a high-current probe. In 2021, Wang et al. [51] reported the HAADF-STEM of Ti3C2 MQDs clusters (Fig. 16(d)) and single Ti3C2 MQDs (Fig. 16(e)), and the Ti3C2 MQDs clusters with different orientation shows clearly grain boundaries and edge defects. This is a great leap for the characterization techniques of MQDs [51]. Interestingly, using the cryo-electron microscopy (Cryo-EM) to parse virus structures at a few angstroms’ resolution inspires us to resolve this deficiency, which enables direct observation of electron beam-sensitive samples with a high spatial resolution. For example, the electron microscopy structure of ACE2 and 2019-nCoVS was identified by Cryo-EM at an angstrom-resolution of 2.9 and 3.5 Å, respectively [127,128]. Such major breakthrough provides a critical direction for drug development. 6.2 In-situ characterization techniques Monitoring the surface variation of catalyst is important for revealing the real catalytic active sites during catalysis. Although surface science techniques have made a rapid development, the visualization (the type, arrangement of atoms) of surface termination and the surface structure decorated by heteroatoms in MQDs, and the visualization of dynamic evolution of active sites of the MQDs-based catalyst, remains a challenge. Currently, there is no application of in-situ techniques in the MQDs-based catalysts for exploring the structure-activity correlation of catalysts, but such unique merits have been presented in other systems [129]. For example, Lee et al. [130] designed the in-situ/operando XAS and Raman spectroscopy experiments, for identifying the intermediate-spin state of Co, and the Fe-CoOOH active phase after electrochemical reconstruction, presenting the real state of CF-FeSO catalyst, enables the fast OER reaction. Figs. 17(a) and 17(d) shows the customized electrochemical cell of Raman and XAS, respectively. The result indicates that the CoO phase of CF-O in 1 mol L–1 KOH will change with applied voltages, resulting in poor phase CoO2 (Fig. 17(b)). However, the highly active CoOOH phase of CF-FeSO was reserved after introducing the Fe and S elements (Fig. 17(c)). Moreover, the oxidation state of Co can also be further confirmed by in-situ/operando XAS, and the XAFS result shows the same valence state as Raman spectrum (Figs. 17(e) and (f)). Therefore, such in-situ characterization technique is very important for identifying the phase transition process during catalytic reaction. In addition, the combination of in-situ/operando scanning probe and X-ray microscopy techniques morphology represent a groundbreaking progress, and it enables directly observing the dynamic catalytic process, showing the morphology and structure of catalyst during reaction. In 2021 [131], the morphology of β-Co(OH)2 nanoparticles at the different voltage were recorded by electrochemical atomic force microscopy (~10 nm spatial resolution). At the different catalytic voltage, the hydroxide intercalation, the interlayer water and protons release induced the phase transform from α-CoO2H1.5·0.5H2O to β-CoOOH particles (Fig. 18(a) ), resulting in the shrinkage and expansion of the β-Co(OH)2 nanoparticles (Fig. 18(b)), which can also be seen from the height map (Fig. 18(c)). Additionally, the operando scanning transmission X-ray microscopy (STXM) was used to characterize the Co oxidation state (Fig. 18(d)) (~50 nm resolution), and Figs. 18(e) and (f) shows that voltage-dependent Co valence, which is correlated to the final OER active phase. Furthermore, the operando X-ray diffraction pattern (Figs. 18(g) and (h)), and operando ambient-pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (APXPS) (Fig. 18(i)) [132,133] can also be used to monitor the surface oxidation state and local atomic-structure transformation of the active sites, contributing to understanding the reaction mechanism, especially in catalysts whose catalytic active sites are transformed via surface reconstruction. Apart from the above mentioned in-situ technique, other characterization such as FTIR [134], in situ liquid cell TEM [135] or quasi-in situ identical location TEM [136] are used to evaluate variation of catalysts during electrochemical reaction. 6.3 Density functional calculation DFT is necessary to reveal real catalytic active site, simulate real reaction path, and judge the rate-determining step, especially in muti-steps reactions. It needs to establish crystal structure model, control external conditions (e.g., temperature, pressure, pH, voltage), and consider appropriately some assumptions and approximations. Therefore, DFT cannot reflect real working conditions, but it is benefited to search for experimental boundary conditions, and guide the design of experiment, avoiding detours. It is well known that the overpotential is an import parameter for evaluating the performance of catalysts. The surface functional groups of MQD as catalytic active sites offers excellent HER, OER, and NRR activities. Thus, the type, contents of groups, and pHs of electrolyte are crucial in DFT consideration. For example, Gao et al. [108] simulated these factors in the MXene (Ti2C, V2C, Nb2C, Ti3C2, Nb4C3), thereby exploring their electrocatalytic HER potential. The type of groups (bare, −O, −OH) apparent affect the conductivity, the exposure of metal atoms offers abundant electrons, enables MXene is metallic (Fig. 19(a) ). However, the electrons transfer of metal-group affect the energy structure (Figs. 19(b) and (c)), impacting on the electrons transfer during catalytic reaction. Moreover, the surface state of catalysts correlates to the voltage and pH values of electrolyte, affecting the catalytic activity. The Pourbaix diagrams are constructed based on the thermodynamically most stable surface state under the relevant USHE and pH values, which shows the oxidation of −OH groups at different applied potential and pHs, determined the relationship between the type of group and pH, potential at standard conditions (Fig. 19(d)). Also, the stability of catalysts can also be calculated (Fig. 19(e)). Such theoretical calculation contributes to screening the conditions and design of optimal catalysts. Sometimes, the dimension of catalysts needs to be considered for promising the gas product timely release, e.g., 3D porous materials, and the amount of gas affect the adsorption of reactant and the stability of catalysts. For instance, Cheng et al. [137] constructed water-solid interface model of Cr2CO2 MXene, and studied the effect of H2O molecules and concentration of protons on the Gibbs free energy (Figs. 19(f) and (g)). The result indicates that the high coverage of H promotes the HER stability of Cr2CO2. Furthermore, the catalytic reaction mechanism often calculated by using transition state search method, mainly involved the reaction barriers in every step. It helps to understand the position of adsorption and desorption of reactants and product, respectively, further determining the catalytic active sites, and rate-determining step of catalysis. Zhou et al. [138] reported the HER performance of MoC Quantum Dots@N- Doped-Carbon. DFT calculation shows the Gibbs free energy of different sample and position, for illustrating the real catalytic active sites. The different structural model has been shown in Figs. 19(h)–(j). The result indicates the excellent catalytic activity is a statistical result of active sites, depending on the interaction of MoC QDs and N-C (Fig. 19(k)). In another instance, the Cu-Ni-based electrocatalyst was studied for understanding the origin of the high catalytic activity [139]. It helps to analyze the roles of every phase, i.e., the Ni helps stabilize the H of Cu surface, and Cr2O3 species promotes the adsorption of H2O and OH. And, the first step (water dissociation) as determining step in neutral water accelerates the overall reaction (Fig. 19(l)). 7 Conclusions and outlook To summarize, initialized from the characteristics of single-atom catalysis and single-site heterogeneous catalysis, we propose the single site chemistry of MQDs, that is the surface functional groups with redox activity as mini-lab, conducts surface modification, including design principles, design strategy, and gives the characterization limitation of MQDs. Therefore, through comparing the role of the surface functional groups of carbon material quantum dots and MQDs, the application prospect of the emerging MQDs is debuting in the field of catalysis. As electrocatalytic activity sites, the surface functional groups play a key role on the performance, and the heteroatoms (transition metal, and non-metal atoms) decoration can further adjust the activity, including the modification of M site, X site, and T site. As co-catalyst, the surface functional groups and energy band structure of MQDs determined the photocatalytic activity and photogenerated carriers’ recombination capability. Thus, it is necessary for constructing MQDs-based heterostructures. Further research is needed to explore the effect of the type of functional groups on regulating the band structure of MQDs and photocatalytic activity. Furthermore, the surface functional groups of MQDs can form layered conductive network with spatial confinement by self-crosslinking and van der Waals interaction, achieving uniform and atomic-level dispersion of active metals and metal semiconductors. Two-dimensional materials derived quantum dots such as CQDs, MoS2 QDs, BP QDs, MQDs etc. [140–144] has aroused great interest due to their excellent electronic conductivity, large surface areas and unique quantum confinement effect, especially in catalysis. However, compared to other QDs, MQDs possess diverse composition, and thereof leading to the diversity of structures, further determining a variety of catalytic performances. Moreover, the surface functional groups can serve as catalytic active sites, which is controllable and modifiable. Such flexible, environmentally friendly and low-cost makes it ideal candidates for noble-metal-free catalysts, and there is lots of space to be achieved for the promising MQDs. Finally, we provide insights into the confronting challenges (Fig. 20 ). (1) Diversity of composition and synthesis. At present, most research focused on the Ti3C2 MQDs. Although the Nb2C MQDs, Ti2C MQDs and V2C MQDs have been synthesized, no reports are found for the application on the catalysis. And, as the “M” metal represents IIIA and IVA elements, more single metal MQDs or dual metal MQDs remains to be prepared for further exploring their physiochemistry properties and catalytic application. Such design of structure and composition helps to achieve excellent performance. (2) The synthesis of fluorine-free MQDs or precursors of MQDs (2D MXene) should be popularized for safe and environmentally friendly application, such as electrochemical etching, molten salts method, and alkaline treatment. Moreover, controlling the surface functional groups of MQDs is of great significance to achieve specific catalytic activities. Especially, the activity of single groups contributes to illustrate the real catalytic active sites, and reveal real catalytic process. (3) Exploring the growth mechanism. The surface functional groups of MQDs are crucial for catalysis. To synthesis MQDs with high purity and excellent structure (desired size, structure, arrangement of functional groups), it is necessary to control the synthesis conditions (e.g., reaction temperature, pressure, and time) and the effect of impurity. And, it is noticed that MQDs are easily oxidized during preparation. Such precise control contributes to analysis of the formation mechanism of MQDs and subsequent characterization. (4) Characterization techniques of MQDs. The surface functional groups with negativity are easily combined with metal ions, which not only can adjust the catalytic activity of MQDs, but also limit the aggregation and growth of metals. The advanced characterization and in-situ techniques should be introduced to explore the interaction mechanism between MQDs and metal, or other heterostructure catalysts, the dynamic variation of active sites, and the structure evolution during catalytic reaction. (5) The aggregation of MQDs during synthesis and catalytic reaction is a major challenge, leading to the difficulty of resolving the surface physicochemical properties of MQDs. Thus, exploring the dispersion of MQDs should focus on the different organic solvent (e.g., ethanol, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)), due to the easily oxidation of MQDs in water solution. Moreover, it is also noticed that the stability of MQDs under high electrons beam irradiation can be resolved by means of Cryo-EM, which helps to guide the structure design of high-efficient catalysis. (6) It is important for achieving diverse applications in catalysis, including electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction, methanol oxidation, and studying their in-depth mechanism to explore the surface chemistry (the role of single functional group, the interactions between functional groups) of MQDs. Currently, MQDs are used as co-catalysts for enhancing the extraction of photogenerated electrons, but there are seldom reports on the effect of surface chemistry on semiconductor behavior and photocatalytic reaction mechanism of MQDs, and the photocatalytic activity of MQDs. In addition, the introduction of single atoms into MQDs is also a direction worth studying based on the surface functional groups. At present, the medical research shows the interaction has been destroyed by the new crown vaccine as an antibody between spike glycoprotein on the surface of the coronavirus and ACE2, meaning that the war without gunpowder has achieved an initial victory. Therefore, the study of the type, arrangement, and physicochemical properties of the surface functional groups of MQDs will also soon succeed, which provides unlimited opportunities for exploring new MQDs, designing high-reactivity MQDs-based catalysts. Wei Zhang (Jilin University) obtained his Ph.D. degree at the Institute of Metal Research Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2004. Then He held positions in NIMS-Japan, Samsung AIT-South Korea, Fritz-Haber Institute of MPG-Germany, DTU-Denmark and CIC Energigune-Spain. He was awarded Ikerbasque Research Professor in 2016. In 2014, he became a full professor at Jilin University and has been selected as Tang Auchin Scholar Leading Professor since 2020; Now he serves as the Director of the Electron Microscopy Center of Jilin University. His current research focuses on surface and interface of advanced energy materials and catalysts. Prof. Zhang was invited as a member of the editorial board of Communications Chemistry at Nature Publishing Group. Weitao Zheng (Jilin University) is Cheung Kong Distinguished Professor and Vice President of Jilin University. He obtained his Ph.D. degree at Jilin University in 1990. After that, he held positions at the Royal Institute of Sweden, Linköping University, Chiba Institute of Technology, and Nanyang University of Technology. His current research focuses on energy materials, functional thin films, and catalysts. Prof. Zheng was invited as an editorial board member of Applied Surface Science and Vacuum.

coredata.dc:description: Scientific research is currently more interdisciplinary. Researchers have parsed the surface structure of virus, constructed the interaction model of virus-receptors, offering the clues for studying efficient targeted drugs. Likewise, catalysis is also highly relevant to modern human life. Exploring the surface structure and physicochemical properties of catalysts is of great significance for the design of efficient catalysts. Great progresses have been made for endowing specific physicochemical properties of catalysts through controlling the size of materials and coordination chemistry of active sites, particularly at nanometer scale since Sir John Meurig Thomas and Tao Zhang's early ground-breaking contribution, with casting on a very surface issue. Herein, functional regulation renders the emerging MXene quantum dots (MQDs) excel in contrast to the typical carbon-based quantum dots. In fact, similar to the interaction of virus-receptors model, the surface functional groups decorated MQDs provide a mini-lab to afford a variety of adjustments, involved with the type modification and electronic structure tuning of groups as well as their arrangement, together with the interaction between the groups and active materials/support, ultimately for packaging or designing high-activity catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Surface chemistry of MXene quantum dots: Virus mechanism-inspired mini-lab for catalysis
